Invariants for subsetting and subassignment

Source: vignettes/invariants.Rmd
invariants.Rmd

This vignette defines invariants for subsetting and subset-assignment for tibbles, and illustrates where their behaviour differs from data frames. The goal is to define a small set of invariants that consistently define how behaviors interact. Some behaviors are defined using functions of the vctrs package, e.g. vctrs::vec_slice(), vctrs::vec_recycle() and vctrs::vec_as_index(). Refer to their documentation for more details about the invariants that they follow.

The subsetting and subassignment operators for data frames and tibbles are particularly tricky, because they support both row and column indexes, both of which are optionally missing. We resolve this by first defining column access with [[ and $, then column-wise subsetting with [, then row-wise subsetting, then the composition of both.

Conventions

In this article, all behaviors are demonstrated using one example data frame and its tibble equivalent:

library(vctrs)
library(tibble)
new_df <- function() {
  df <- data.frame(n = 1:4)
  df$c <- letters[5:8]
  df$li <- list(9, 10:11, 12:14, "text")
  df
}
new_tbl <- function() {
  as_tibble(new_df())
}

Results of the same code for data frames and tibbles are presented side by side:

new_df()
#>   n c         li
#> 1 1 e          9
#> 2 2 f     10, 11
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 4 h       text
 
new_tbl()
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>

If the results are identical (after converting to a data frame if necessary), only the tibble result is shown.

Subsetting operations are read-only. The same objects are reused in all examples:

df <- new_df()
tbl <- new_tbl()

Where needed, we also show examples with hierarchical columns containing a data frame or a matrix:

new_tbl2 <- function() {
  tibble(
    tb = tbl,
    m = diag(4)
  )
}
new_df2 <- function() {
  df2 <- new_tbl2()
  class(df2) <- "data.frame"
  class(df2$tb) <- "data.frame"
  df2
}
df2 <- new_df2()
tbl2 <- new_tbl2()
new_tbl()
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>

For subset assignment (subassignment, for short), we need a fresh copy of the data for each test. The with_*() functions (omitted here for brevity) allow for a more concise notation. These functions take an assignment expression, execute it on a fresh copy of the data, and return the data for printing. The first example prints whatâ€™s really executed, further examples omit this output.

with_df(df$n <- rev(df$n), verbose = TRUE)
#> {
#>   df <- new_df()
#>   df$n <- rev(df$n)
#>   df
#> }
#>   n c         li
#> 1 4 e          9
#> 2 3 f     10, 11
#> 3 2 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 1 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl$n <- rev(tbl$n), verbose = TRUE)
#> {
#>   tbl <- new_tbl()
#>   tbl$n <- rev(tbl$n)
#>   tbl
#> }
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     4 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     3 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     2 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     1 h     <chr [1]>

Column extraction

Definition of x[[j]]

x[[j]] is equal to .subset2(x, j).

tbl[[1]]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
.subset2(tbl, 1)
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
identical(tbl[[3]], .subset2(tbl, 3))
#> [1] TRUE
 
identical(tbl2[["tbl"]], .subset2(tbl2, "tbl"))
#> [1] TRUE

NB: x[[j]] always returns an object of size nrow(x) if the column exists.

vec_size(tbl[[1]])
#> [1] 4
 
vec_size(tbl[[3]])
#> [1] 4
 
vec_size(tbl2[[1]])
#> [1] 4
 
vec_size(tbl2[[2]])
#> [1] 4

j must be a single number or a string, as enforced by .subset2(x, j).

df[[1:2]]
#> [1] 2
 
tbl[[1:2]]
#> Warning: Calling `[[` with a vector
#> of length 2 (recursive subsetting)
#> is deprecated and will eventually be
#> converted to an error.
#> [1] 2
 
df[[c("n", "c")]]
#> Error in .subset2(x, i, exact =
#> exact): subscript out of bounds
 
tbl[[c("n", "c")]]
#> Error in error_need_scalar(): could
#> not find function
#> "error_need_scalar"
 
df[[TRUE]]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
tbl[[TRUE]]
#> Error in
#> error_double_bracket_logical():
#> could not find function
#> "error_double_bracket_logical"
 
df[[mean]]
#> Error in .subset2(x, i, exact =
#> exact): invalid subscript type
#> 'closure'
 
tbl[[mean]]
#> Error in .subset2(x, j): invalid
#> subscript type 'closure'

NA indexes, numeric out-of-bounds (OOB) values, and non-integers throw an error:

tbl[[NA]]
#> NULL
 
tbl[[NA_character_]] # FIXME
#> NULL
 
tbl[[NA_integer_]] # FIXME
#> NULL
 
df[[-1]]
#> Error in .subset2(x, i, exact =
#> exact): attempt to select more than
#> one element in get1index <real>
 
tbl[[-1]]
#> Error in error_need_scalar(): could
#> not find function
#> "error_need_scalar"
 
df[[4]]
#> Error in .subset2(x, i, exact =
#> exact): subscript out of bounds
 
tbl[[4]]
#> Error: Can't index beyond the end of
#> a vector.
#> The vector has length 3 and you've
#> tried to subset element 4.
 
df[[1.5]]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
tbl[[1.5]]
#> Lossy cast from <double> to
#> <integer>.
#> Locations: 1
 
df[[Inf]]
#> NULL
 
tbl[[Inf]]
#> Lossy cast from <double> to
#> <integer>.
#> Locations: 1

Character OOB access is silent because a common package idiom is to check for the absence of a column with is.null(df[[var]]).

tbl[["x"]]
#> NULL

Definition of x$name

x$name and x$"name" are equal to x[["name"]].

tbl$n
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
tbl$"n"
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
tbl[["n"]]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
identical(tbl$li, tbl[["li"]])
#> [1] TRUE
 
identical(tbl2$tb, tbl2[["tb"]])
#> [1] TRUE
 
identical(tbl2$m, tbl2[["m"]])
#> [1] TRUE

Unlike data frames, tibbles do not partially match names.

df$l
#> [[1]]
#> [1] 9
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] 10 11
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] 12 13 14
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] "text"
 
tbl$l
#> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised
#> column: `l`.
#> NULL

Because df$x is rarely used in packages, it can raise a warning:

df$not_present
#> NULL
 
tbl$not_present
#> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised
#> column: `not_present`.
#> NULL

Column subsetting

Definition of x[j].

j is converted to an integer vector by vctrs::vec_as_index(j, ncol(x), names = names(x)). Then x[c(j_1, j_2, ..., j_n)] is equivalent to tibble(x[[j_1]], x[[j_2]], ..., x[[j_3]]), keeping the corresponding column names. This implies that j must be a numeric or character vector, or a logical vector with length 1 or ncol(x).1

tbl[1:2]
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>       n c    
#>   <int> <chr>
#> 1     1 e    
#> 2     2 f    
#> 3     3 g    
#> 4     4 h

When subsetting repeated indexes, the resulting column names are undefined, do not rely on them.

df[c(1, 1)]
#>   n n.1
#> 1 1   1
#> 2 2   2
#> 3 3   3
#> 4 4   4
 
tbl[c(1, 1)]
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>       n     n
#>   <int> <int>
#> 1     1     1
#> 2     2     2
#> 3     3     3
#> 4     4     4

For tibbles with repeated column names, subsetting by name uses the first matching column.

nrow(df[j]) equals nrow(df).

tbl[integer()]
#> # A tibble: 4 x 0

Definition of x[, j]

x[, j] is equal to x[j]. Tibbles do not perform column extraction if x[j] would yield a single column.

df[, 1]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
tbl[, 1]
#> # A tibble: 4 x 1
#>       n
#>   <int>
#> 1     1
#> 2     2
#> 3     3
#> 4     4
 
tbl[, 1:2]
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>       n c    
#>   <int> <chr>
#> 1     1 e    
#> 2     2 f    
#> 3     3 g    
#> 4     4 h
 
identical(tbl[, 2:3], tbl[2:3])
#> [1] TRUE
 
identical(tbl2[, 1:2], tbl2[1:2])
#> [1] TRUE

Definition of x[, j, drop = TRUE]

For backward compatiblity, x[, j, drop = TRUE] performs column extraction, returning x[j][[1]] when ncol(x[j]) is 1.

tbl[, 1, drop = TRUE]
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
 
identical(tbl[, 3, drop = TRUE], tbl[[3]])
#> [1] TRUE
 
identical(tbl2[, 1, drop = TRUE], tbl2[[1]])
#> [1] TRUE
 
identical(tbl2[, 2, drop = TRUE], tbl2[[2]])
#> [1] TRUE

Row subsetting

Definition of x[i, ]

x[i, ] is equal to tibble(vec_slice(x[[1]], i), vec_slice(x[[2]], i), ...).2

tbl[3, ]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     3 g     <int [3]>

This means that i must be a numeric vector, or a logical vector of length nrow(x) or 1. For compatibility, i can also be a character vector containing positive numbers.

df[mean, ]
#> Error in xj[i]: invalid subscript
#> type 'closure'
 
tbl[mean, ]
#> Error: `i` must be an integer,
#> character, or logical vector, not a
#> closure.
 
df[list(1), ]
#> Error in xj[i]: invalid subscript
#> type 'list'
 
tbl[list(1), ]
#> Error: `i` must be an integer,
#> character, or logical vector, not a
#> list.
 
tbl["1", ]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>

Exception: OOB values generate warnings instead of errors:

df[10, ]
#>     n    c   li
#> NA NA <NA> NULL
 
tbl[10, ]
#> Warning: Row indexes must be between 0
#> and the number of rows (4). Use `NA` as
#> row index to obtain a row full of `NA`
#> values.
#> # A tibble: 1 x 3
#>       n c     li    
#>   <int> <chr> <list>
#> 1    NA <NA>  <NULL>
 
df["x", ]
#>     n    c   li
#> NA NA <NA> NULL
 
tbl["x", ]
#> Warning: Only valid row names can be
#> used for indexing. Use `NA` as row index
#> to obtain a row full of `NA` values.
#> # A tibble: 1 x 3
#>       n c     li    
#>   <int> <chr> <list>
#> 1    NA <NA>  <NULL>

Unlike data frames, only logical vectors of length 1 are recycled. 

df[c(TRUE, FALSE), ]
#>   n c         li
#> 1 1 e          9
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14
 
tbl[c(TRUE, FALSE), ]
#> Warning: Length of logical index must be
#> 1 or 4, not 2
#> # A tibble: 2 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     3 g     <int [3]>

NB: scalar logicals are recycled, but scalar numerics are not. That makes the x[NA, ] and x[NA_integer_, ] return different results.

tbl[NA, ]
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li    
#>   <int> <chr> <list>
#> 1    NA <NA>  <NULL>
#> 2    NA <NA>  <NULL>
#> 3    NA <NA>  <NULL>
#> 4    NA <NA>  <NULL>
 
tbl[NA_integer_, ]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 3
#>       n c     li    
#>   <int> <chr> <list>
#> 1    NA <NA>  <NULL>

Definition of x[i, , drop = TRUE]

drop = TRUE has no effect when not selecting a single row:

df[1, , drop = TRUE]
#> $n
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $c
#> [1] "e"
#> 
#> $li
#> $li[[1]]
#> [1] 9
 
tbl[1, , drop = TRUE]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>

Row and column subsetting

Definition of x[] and x[,]

x[] and x[,] are equivalent to x.3

Definition of x[i, j]

x[i, j] is equal to x[i, ][j].4

df[1, 1]
#> [1] 1
 
tbl[1, 1]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 1
#>       n
#>   <int>
#> 1     1
 
tbl[1, ][1]
#> # A tibble: 1 x 1
#>       n
#>   <int>
#> 1     1
 
identical(tbl[1, 2:3], tbl[2:3][1, ])
#> [1] TRUE
 
identical(tbl[2:3, 1], tbl[1][2:3, ])
#> [1] TRUE
 
identical(tbl2[2:3, 1:2], tbl2[1:2][2:3, ])
#> [1] TRUE

Definition of x[[i, j]]

i must be a numeric vector of length 1. x[[i, j]] is equal to x[i, ][[j]].5

This implies that j must be a numeric or character vector of length 1.

NB: vctrs::vec_size(x[[i, j]]) always equals 1. Unlike x[i, ], x[[i, ]] is not valid.

Column update

Definition of x[[j]] <- a.

x[[j]] <- a corresponds to x <- tibble(x[[j_1]], x[[j_2]], ..., a, ..., x[[j_n]]).

with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <dbl> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     0 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     0 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[[3]] <- 4:1)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c        li
#>   <int> <chr> <int>
#> 1     1 e         4
#> 2     2 f         3
#> 3     3 g         2
#> 4     4 h         1
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[1]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>      tb m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4]
#>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     0     1     0     0     0
#> 2     0     0     1     0     0
#> 3     0     0     0     1     0
#> 4     0     0     0     0     1
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[2]] <- 4:1)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li           m
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <int>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     4
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>     3
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>     2
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>     1

For this, j must be a scalar numeric or a string, and cannot be NA.

with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <dbl> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     0 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     0 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[["c"]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n     c li       
#>   <int> <dbl> <list>   
#> 1     1     0 <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2     0 <int [2]>
#> 3     3     0 <int [3]>
#> 4     4     0 <chr [1]>
 
with_df(df[[TRUE]] <- 0)
#>   n c         li
#> 1 0 e          9
#> 2 0 f     10, 11
#> 3 0 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 0 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[[TRUE]] <- 0)
#> Error in error_need_scalar(): could
#> not find function
#> "error_need_scalar"
 
with_df(df[[1:3]] <- 0)
#> Error in `[[<-`(`*tmp*`, i, value =
#> value): recursive indexing failed at
#> level 2
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1:3]] <- 0)
#> Error in error_need_scalar(): could
#> not find function
#> "error_need_scalar"
 
with_df(df[[c("n", "c")]] <- 0)
#> Error in x[[i]] <- value: more
#> elements supplied than there are to
#> replace
 
with_tbl(tbl[[c("n", "c")]] <- 0)
#> Error in error_need_scalar(): could
#> not find function
#> "error_need_scalar"
 
with_df(df[[FALSE]] <- 0)
#> Error in x[[i]] <- value: attempt to
#> select less than one element in
#> integerOneIndex
 
with_tbl(tbl[[FALSE]] <- 0)
#> Error in error_need_scalar(): could
#> not find function
#> "error_need_scalar"
 
with_df(df[[1:2]] <- 0)
#> Error in x[[i]] <- value: more
#> elements supplied than there are to
#> replace
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1:2]] <- 0)
#> Error in error_need_scalar(): could
#> not find function
#> "error_need_scalar"
 
with_df(df[[NA_integer_]] <- 0)
#> Error in x[[i]] <- value: attempt to
#> select more than one element in
#> integerOneIndex
 
with_tbl(tbl[[NA_integer_]] <- 0)
#> Error in
#> error_new_columns_non_na_only():
#> could not find function
#> "error_new_columns_non_na_only"
 
with_df(df[[NA]] <- 0)
#> Error in x[[i]] <- value: attempt to
#> select more than one element in
#> integerOneIndex
 
with_tbl(tbl[[NA]] <- 0)
#> Error in
#> error_new_columns_non_na_only():
#> could not find function
#> "error_new_columns_non_na_only"
 
with_df(df[[NA_character_]] <- 0)
#> Error in if (names(x)[nc] == "")
#> names(x)[nc] <- paste0("V", nc):
#> missing value where TRUE/FALSE
#> needed
 
with_tbl(tbl[[NA_character_]] <- 0)
#> Error in
#> error_new_columns_non_na_only():
#> could not find function
#> "error_new_columns_non_na_only"

vec_size(a) must be nrow(x) or 1. Recycling also works for list, data frame, and matrix columns.

with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- 1)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <dbl> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     1 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     1 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     1 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- 4:1)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     4 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     3 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     2 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     1 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df(df[[1]] <- 3:1)
#> Error in `[[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 1, value = 3:1): replacement has 3
#> rows, data has 4
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- 3:1)
#> Vector of length 3 cannot be
#> recycled to
#> length 4. Only vectors of length one
#> can
#> be recycled.
 
with_df(df[[1]] <- 2:1)
#>   n c         li
#> 1 2 e          9
#> 2 1 f     10, 11
#> 3 2 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 1 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- 2:1)
#> Vector of length 2 cannot be
#> recycled to
#> length 4. Only vectors of length one
#> can
#> be recycled.
 
with_tbl(tbl[["li"]] <- list(0))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <dbl [1]>
#> 3     3 g     <dbl [1]>
#> 4     4 h     <dbl [1]>
 
with_df2(df2[["tb"]] <- df[1, ])
#> Error in `[[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> "tb", value = structure(list(n = 1L,
#> : replacement has 1 row, data has 4
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[["tb"]] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li      m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 2     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     0     1     0
#> 3     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     0     0     1
#> 4     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     0     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
with_df2(df2[["m"]] <- df2[["m"]][1, , drop = FALSE])
#> Error in `[[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> "m", value = structure(c(1, 0, 0, :
#> replacement has 1 row, data has 4
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[["m"]] <- tbl2[["m"]][1, , drop = FALSE])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li      m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2â€¦     1     0     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3â€¦     1     0     0
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>

New columns are appended at the end, with name repair if needed.

with_tbl(tbl[["x"]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 4
#>       n c     li            x
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>     0
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>     0
 
with_df(df[[4]] <- 0)
#>   n c         li V4
#> 1 1 e          9  0
#> 2 2 f     10, 11  0
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14  0
#> 4 4 h       text  0
 
with_tbl(tbl[[4]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 4
#>       n c     li         ...4
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>     0
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>     0
 
with_df(df[[5]] <- 0)
#> Warning in format.data.frame(if (omit)
#> x[seq_len(n0), , drop = FALSE] else
#> x, : corrupt data frame: columns will be
#> truncated or padded with NAs
#>   n c         li      V5
#> 1 1 e          9 NULL  0
#> 2 2 f     10, 11 <NA>  0
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14 <NA>  0
#> 4 4 h       text <NA>  0
 
with_tbl(tbl[[5]] <- 0)
#> Error in
#> error_new_columns_at_end_only():
#> could not find function
#> "error_new_columns_at_end_only"

The type of an existing column can be changed, also across the principal column types:

  • atomic: df[[1]] and df[[2]]
  • list: df[[3]]
  • data frame: df2[[1]]
  • matrix: df2[[2]] 
with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- tbl[[2]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   n     c     li       
#>   <chr> <chr> <list>   
#> 1 e     e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2 f     f     <int [2]>
#> 3 g     g     <int [3]>
#> 4 h     h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[[2]] <- tbl[[3]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c         li       
#>   <int> <list>    <list>   
#> 1     1 <dbl [1]> <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 <int [2]> <int [2]>
#> 3     3 <int [3]> <int [3]>
#> 4     4 <chr [1]> <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[[3]] <- tbl2[[1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c      li$n $c    $li      
#>   <int> <chr> <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e         1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f         2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g         3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h         4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[1]] <- tbl2[[2]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>   tb[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4] m[,1]  [,2]
#>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1      1     0     0     0     1     0
#> 2      0     1     0     0     0     1
#> 3      0     0     1     0     0     0
#> 4      0     0     0     1     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 2 more variables: [,3] <dbl>,
#> #   [,4] <dbl>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[2]] <- tbl[[1]])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li           m
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <int>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     1
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>     2
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>     3
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>     4

[[<- supports removing a column by assigning NULL to it.

with_tbl(tbl[[1]] <- NULL)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>   c     li       
#>   <chr> <list>   
#> 1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[2]] <- NULL)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 1
#>    tb$n $c    $li      
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>

Definition of x$name <- a.

x$name <- a and x$"name" <- a are equivalent to x[["name"]] <- a.6

with_tbl(tbl$n <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <dbl> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     0 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     0 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl$"n" <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <dbl> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     0 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     0 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[["n"]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <dbl> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     0 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     0 h     <chr [1]>

$ does not implement partial matching but creates a new column.

with_tbl(tbl$l <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 4
#>       n c     li            l
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>     0
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>     0
 
with_tbl(tbl[["l"]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 4
#>       n c     li            l
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>     0
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>     0

Definition of x[j] <- list(...).

x[j] <- a is equivalent to performing x[[j_1]] <- a[[1]], x[[j_2]] <- a[[2]] etc. If a contains NULL values, the corresponding columns are removed after updating. 
with_tbl(tbl[1:2] <- list("x", 4:1))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   n         c li       
#>   <chr> <int> <list>   
#> 1 x         4 <dbl [1]>
#> 2 x         3 <int [2]>
#> 3 x         2 <int [3]>
#> 4 x         1 <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[c("li", "x", "c")] <- list("x", 4:1, NULL))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n li        x
#>   <int> <chr> <int>
#> 1     1 x         4
#> 2     2 x         3
#> 3     3 x         2
#> 4     4 x         1
 
with_tbl(tbl[1:2] <- list(NULL, 4:1))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>       c li       
#>   <int> <list>   
#> 1     4 <dbl [1]>
#> 2     3 <int [2]>
#> 3     2 <int [3]>
#> 4     1 <chr [1]>

NA indexes are not supported.

with_df(df[NA] <- list("x"))
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> NA, value = list("x")): missing
#> values are not allowed in
#> subscripted assignments of data
#> frames
 
with_tbl(tbl[NA] <- list("x"))
#> Error in
#> error_new_columns_non_na_only():
#> could not find function
#> "error_new_columns_non_na_only"
 
with_df(df[NA_integer_] <- list("x"))
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> NA_integer_, value = list("x")):
#> missing values are not allowed in
#> subscripted assignments of data
#> frames
 
with_tbl(tbl[NA_integer_] <- list("x"))
#> Error in
#> error_new_columns_non_na_only():
#> could not find function
#> "error_new_columns_non_na_only"
 
with_df(df[NA_character_] <- list("x"))
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> NA_character_, value = list("x")):
#> missing values are not allowed in
#> subscripted assignments of data
#> frames
 
with_tbl(tbl[NA_character_] <- list("x"))
#> Error in
#> error_new_columns_non_na_only():
#> could not find function
#> "error_new_columns_non_na_only"

Just like column updates, [<- supports changing the type of an existing column, also across the principal column types:

  • atomic: df[[1]] and df[[2]]
  • list: df[[3]]
  • data frame: df2[[1]]
  • matrix: df2[[2]] 
with_tbl(tbl[1] <- tbl[2])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   n     c     li       
#>   <chr> <chr> <list>   
#> 1 e     e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2 f     f     <int [2]>
#> 3 g     g     <int [3]>
#> 4 h     h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[2] <- tbl[3])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c         li       
#>   <int> <list>    <list>   
#> 1     1 <dbl [1]> <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 <int [2]> <int [2]>
#> 3     3 <int [3]> <int [3]>
#> 4     4 <chr [1]> <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[3] <- tbl2[1])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c      li$n $c    $li      
#>   <int> <chr> <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e         1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f         2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g         3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h         4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[1] <- tbl2[2])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>   tb[,1]  [,2]  [,3]  [,4] m[,1]  [,2]
#>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1      1     0     0     0     1     0
#> 2      0     1     0     0     0     1
#> 3      0     0     1     0     0     0
#> 4      0     0     0     1     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 2 more variables: [,3] <dbl>,
#> #   [,4] <dbl>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[2] <- tbl[1])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li           m
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <int>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     1
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>     2
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>     3
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>     4

Appending columns at the end (without gaps) is supported. The name of new columns is determined by the LHS, the RHS, or by name repair (in that order of precedence).

with_tbl(tbl[c("x", "y")] <- tibble("x", x = 4:1))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 5
#>       n c     li        x         y
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <chr> <int>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]> x         4
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]> x         3
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]> x         2
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]> x         1
 
with_tbl(tbl[3:4] <- list("x", x = 4:1))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 4
#>       n c     li        x
#>   <int> <chr> <chr> <int>
#> 1     1 e     x         4
#> 2     2 f     x         3
#> 3     3 g     x         2
#> 4     4 h     x         1
 
with_df(df[4] <- list(4:1))
#>   n c         li V4
#> 1 1 e          9  4
#> 2 2 f     10, 11  3
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14  2
#> 4 4 h       text  1
 
with_tbl(tbl[4] <- list(4:1))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 4
#>       n c     li         ...4
#>   <int> <chr> <list>    <int>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>     4
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>     3
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>     2
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>     1
 
with_df(df[5] <- list(4:1))
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 5, value = list(4:1)): new columns
#> would leave holes after existing
#> columns
 
with_tbl(tbl[5] <- list(4:1))
#> Error in
#> error_new_columns_at_end_only():
#> could not find function
#> "error_new_columns_at_end_only"

Definition of x[j] <- list(a).

x[j] <- a is equivalent to x[j] <- rep_along(j, a) if is_list(a, 1).

with_tbl(tbl[1:2] <- list(0))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n     c li       
#>   <dbl> <dbl> <list>   
#> 1     0     0 <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0     0 <int [2]>
#> 3     0     0 <int [3]>
#> 4     0     0 <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[1:2] <- list(0, 0))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n     c li       
#>   <dbl> <dbl> <list>   
#> 1     0     0 <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0     0 <int [2]>
#> 3     0     0 <int [3]>
#> 4     0     0 <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[1:3] <- list(0))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n     c    li
#>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     0     0     0
#> 2     0     0     0
#> 3     0     0     0
#> 4     0     0     0
 
with_tbl(tbl[1:3] <- list(0, 0, 0))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n     c    li
#>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     0     0     0
#> 2     0     0     0
#> 3     0     0     0
#> 4     0     0     0

This means that only lists of length one on the RHS are recycled.

with_df(df[1:2] <- list(0, 0, 0))
#> Warning in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 1:2, value = list(0, 0, 0)): provided 3
#> variables to replace 2 variables
#>   n c         li
#> 1 0 0          9
#> 2 0 0     10, 11
#> 3 0 0 12, 13, 14
#> 4 0 0       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[1:2] <- list(0, 0, 0))
#> Vector of length 3 cannot be
#> recycled to
#> length 2. Only vectors of length one
#> can
#> be recycled.
 
with_df(df[1:3] <- list(0, 0))
#>   n c li
#> 1 0 0  0
#> 2 0 0  0
#> 3 0 0  0
#> 4 0 0  0
 
with_tbl(tbl[1:3] <- list(0, 0))
#> Vector of length 2 cannot be
#> recycled to
#> length 3. Only vectors of length one
#> can
#> be recycled.

Definition of x[j] <- a.

x[j] <- a is equivalent to x[j] <- list(a) if is_atomic(a) or is_null(a).

with_tbl(tbl[1] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <dbl> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     0 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     0 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[1] <- list(0))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <dbl> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     0 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     0 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     0 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[1] <- list(list(0)))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   n         c     li       
#>   <list>    <chr> <list>   
#> 1 <dbl [1]> e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2 <dbl [1]> f     <int [2]>
#> 3 <dbl [1]> g     <int [3]>
#> 4 <dbl [1]> h     <chr [1]>

Definition of x[] <- ....

x[] <- ... is equivalent to x[seq_len(ncol(x))] <- ....

with_tbl(tbl[] <- tbl)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 3     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 4     1 e     <dbl [1]>
 
with_df(df[] <- df[1:2, ])
#>   n c     li
#> 1 1 e      9
#> 2 2 f 10, 11
#> 3 1 e      9
#> 4 2 f 10, 11
 
with_tbl(tbl[] <- tbl[1:2, ])
#> Vector of length 2 cannot be
#> recycled to
#> length 4. Only vectors of length one
#> can
#> be recycled.
 
with_df(df[] <- df2)
#>   n.n n.c       n.li c.1 c.2 c.3 c.4
#> 1   1   e          9   1   0   0   0
#> 2   2   f     10, 11   0   1   0   0
#> 3   3   g 12, 13, 14   0   0   1   0
#> 4   4   h       text   0   0   0   1

#> 1    1    e          9
#> 2    2    f     10, 11
#> 3    3    g 12, 13, 14
#> 4    4    h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[] <- tbl2)
#> Vector of length 2 cannot be
#> recycled to
#> length 3. Only vectors of length one
#> can
#> be recycled.
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[] <- tbl2)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li      m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2â€¦     0     1     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3â€¦     0     0     1
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1â€¦     0     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
with_df2(df2[] <- df2[1, ])
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`, ,
#> value = structure(list(tb =
#> structure(list(: replacement element
#> 1 is a matrix/data frame of 1 row,
#> need 4
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[] <- tbl2[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li      m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 2     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 3     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 4     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
with_df2(df2[] <- df2[1:2, ])
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`, ,
#> value = structure(list(tb =
#> structure(list(: replacement element
#> 1 is a matrix/data frame of 2 rows,
#> need 4
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[] <- tbl2[1:2, ])

#> recycled to
#> length 4. Only vectors of length one
#> can
#> be recycled.
 
with_df2(df2[] <- df)
#> Warning in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`, ,
#> value = structure(list(n = 1:4, c =
#> c("e", : provided 3 variables to replace
#> 2 variables
#>   tb m
#> 1  1 e
#> 2  2 f
#> 3  3 g
#> 4  4 h
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[] <- tbl)
#> Vector of length 3 cannot be
#> recycled to
#> length 2. Only vectors of length one
#> can
#> be recycled.

Row subassignment

Definition of x[i, ] <- list(...).

x[i, ] <- a is the same as vec_slice(x[[j_1]], i) <- a[[1]], vec_slice(x[[j_2]], i) <- a[[2]], â€¦ .7

with_tbl(tbl[2:3, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 3     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[c(FALSE, TRUE, TRUE, FALSE), ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 3     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[0:2, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[0, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[-2, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 4     1 e     <dbl [1]>
 
with_df(df[-1:2, ] <- df[1, ])
#> Error in seq_len(nrows)[i]: only 0's
#> may be mixed with negative
#> subscripts
 
with_tbl(tbl[-1:2, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Error: Can't subset with a mix of
#> negative and positive indices
 
with_df(df[NA_integer_, ] <- df[1, ])
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> NA_integer_, , value =
#> structure(list(: missing values are
#> not allowed in subscripted
#> assignments of data frames
 
with_tbl(tbl[NA_integer_, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Error in error_na_new_row(): could
#> not find function "error_na_new_row"
 
with_df2(df2[NA_integer_, ] <- df2[1, ])
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> NA_integer_, , value =
#> structure(list(: missing values are
#> not allowed in subscripted
#> assignments of data frames
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[NA_integer_, ] <- tbl2[1, ])
#> Error in error_na_new_row(): could
#> not find function "error_na_new_row"
 
with_tbl(tbl[TRUE, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 3     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 4     1 e     <dbl [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[FALSE, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df(df[NA, ] <- df[1, ])
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> NA, , value = structure(list(n = 1L,
#> : missing values are not allowed in
#> subscripted assignments of data
#> frames
 
with_tbl(tbl[NA, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Error in error_na_new_row(): could
#> not find function "error_na_new_row"

Only values of size one can be recycled.


with_tbl(tbl[2:3, ] <- tbl[1, ])
with_df(df[2:3, ] <- list(df$n[1], df$c[1:2], df$li[1])
with_tbl(tbl[2:3, ] <- list(tbl$n[1], tbl$c[1:2], tbl$li[1])
with_df(df[2:4, ] <- df[1:2, ])
with_tbl(tbl[2:4, ] <- tbl[1:2, ])
#> Error: <text>:4:1: unexpected symbol
#> 3: with_df(df[2:3, ] <-
#> list(df$n[1], df$c[1:2], df$li[1])
#> 4: with_tbl
#> ^
 
with_df2(df2[2:4, ] <- df2[1, ])
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 2:4, , value = structure(list(tb =
#> structure(list(: replacement element
#> 1 is a matrix/data frame of 1 row,
#> need 3
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[2:4, ] <- tbl2[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li      m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 2     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 3     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 4     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
with_df2(df2[2:4, ] <- df2[2:3, ])
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 2:4, , value = structure(list(tb =
#> structure(list(: replacement element
#> 1 is a matrix/data frame of 2 rows,
#> need 3
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[2:4, ] <- tbl2[2:3, ])
#> Vector of length 2 cannot be
#> recycled to
#> length 3. Only vectors of length one
#> can
#> be recycled.

For compatibility reasons only a warning is issued for indexing beyond the number of rows. Appending rows right at the end of the existing data is supported, without warning.

with_tbl(tbl[5, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 5 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
#> 5     1 e     <dbl [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[5:7, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 7 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
#> 5     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 6     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 7     1 e     <dbl [1]>
 
with_df(df[6, ] <- df[1, ])
#>    n    c         li
#> 1  1    e          9
#> 2  2    f     10, 11
#> 3  3    g 12, 13, 14
#> 4  4    h       text
#> 5 NA <NA>       NULL
#> 6  1    e          9
 
with_tbl(tbl[6, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Error in
#> error_new_rows_at_end_only(): could
#> not find function
#> "error_new_rows_at_end_only"
 
with_df(df[-5, ] <- df[1, ])
#>   n c li
#> 1 1 e  9
#> 2 1 e  9
#> 3 1 e  9
#> 4 1 e  9
 
with_tbl(tbl[-5, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Error: Can't index beyond the end of
#> a vector.
#> The vector has length 4 and you've
#> tried to subset element 5.
 
with_df(df[-(5:7), ] <- df[1, ])
#>   n c li
#> 1 1 e  9
#> 2 1 e  9
#> 3 1 e  9
#> 4 1 e  9
 
with_tbl(tbl[-(5:7), ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Error: Can't index beyond the end of
#> a vector.
#> The vector has length 4 and you've
#> tried to subset element 5.
 
with_df(df[-6, ] <- df[1, ])
#>   n c li
#> 1 1 e  9
#> 2 1 e  9
#> 3 1 e  9
#> 4 1 e  9
 
with_tbl(tbl[-6, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Error: Can't index beyond the end of
#> a vector.
#> The vector has length 4 and you've
#> tried to subset element 6.

For compatibility, i can also be a character vector containing positive numbers.

with_tbl(tbl[as.character(1:3), ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 3     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df(df[as.character(-(1:3)), ] <- df[1, ])
#>    n c         li
#> 1  1 e          9
#> 2  2 f     10, 11
#> 3  3 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4  4 h       text
#> -1 1 e          9
#> -2 1 e          9
#> -3 1 e          9
 
with_tbl(tbl[as.character(-(1:3)), ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Warning: Only valid row names can be
#> used for indexing. Use `NA` as row index
#> to obtain a row full of `NA` values.
#> Error in error_na_new_row(): could
#> not find function "error_na_new_row"
 
with_df(df[as.character(3:5), ] <- df[1, ])
#>   n c     li
#> 1 1 e      9
#> 2 2 f 10, 11
#> 3 1 e      9
#> 4 1 e      9
#> 5 1 e      9
 
with_tbl(tbl[as.character(3:5), ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Warning: Only valid row names can be
#> used for indexing. Use `NA` as row index
#> to obtain a row full of `NA` values.
#> Error in error_na_new_row(): could
#> not find function "error_na_new_row"
 
with_df(df[as.character(-(3:5)), ] <- df[1, ])
#>    n c         li
#> 1  1 e          9
#> 2  2 f     10, 11
#> 3  3 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4  4 h       text
#> -3 1 e          9
#> -4 1 e          9
#> -5 1 e          9
 
with_tbl(tbl[as.character(-(3:5)), ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Warning: Only valid row names can be
#> used for indexing. Use `NA` as row index
#> to obtain a row full of `NA` values.
#> Error in error_na_new_row(): could
#> not find function "error_na_new_row"
 
with_df(df[NA_character_, ] <- df[1, ])
#> Error in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> NA_character_, , value =
#> structure(list(: missing values are
#> not allowed in subscripted
#> assignments of data frames
 
with_tbl(tbl[NA_character_, ] <- tbl[1, ])
#> Error in error_na_new_row(): could
#> not find function "error_na_new_row"

Row and column subassignment

Definition of x[i, j] <- a.

x[i, j] <- a is equivalent to x[i, ][j] <- a.8

Subassignment to x[i, j] is much stricter for tibbles than for data frames. x[i, j] <- a can update only existing columns, it cannot create or remove columns.

with_df(df[2:3, "n"] <- 1)
#>   n c         li
#> 1 1 e          9
#> 2 1 f     10, 11
#> 3 1 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 4 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[2:3, "n"] <- 1)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     1 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     1 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df(df[2:3, "x"] <- 1)
#>   n c         li  x
#> 1 1 e          9 NA
#> 2 2 f     10, 11  1
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14  1
#> 4 4 h       text NA
 
with_tbl(tbl[2:3, "x"] <- 1)
#> Error: Can't index non-existing
#> elements.
 
with_df(df[2:3, "n"] <- NULL)
#> Error in x[[jj]][iseq] <- vjj:
#> replacement has length zero
 
with_tbl(tbl[2:3, "n"] <- NULL)
#> `value` must be a vector, not NULL

x[i, j] <- a canâ€™t change the data type of existing columns.

with_df(df[2:3, 1] <- df[1:2, 2])
#>   n c         li
#> 1 1 e          9
#> 2 e f     10, 11
#> 3 f g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 4 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[2:3, 1] <- tbl[1:2, 2])
#> No common type for `value`
#> <character>
#> and `x` <integer>.
 
with_df(df[2:3, 2] <- df[1:2, 3])
#> Warning in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 2:3, 2, value = list(9, 10:11)):
#> provided 2 variables to replace 1
#> variables
#>   n c         li
#> 1 1 e          9
#> 2 2 9     10, 11
#> 3 3 9 12, 13, 14
#> 4 4 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[2:3, 2] <- tbl[1:2, 3])
#> No common type for `value` <list>
#> and
#> `x` <character>.
 
with_df(df[2:3, 3] <- df2[1:2, 1])
#> Warning in `[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 2:3, 3, value = structure(list(n =
#> 1:2, : provided 3 variables to replace 1
#> variables
#>   n c   li
#> 1 1 e    9
#> 2 2 f    1
#> 3 3 g    2
#> 4 4 h text
 
with_tbl(tbl[2:3, 3] <- tbl2[1:2, 1])
#> No common type for `x` <tbl_df<
#> n : integer
#> c : character
#> li: list
#> >> and `y` <list>.
 
with_df2(df2[2:3, 1] <- df2[1:2, 2])
#> Warning in matrix(value, n, p): data
#> length [8] is not a sub-multiple or
#> multiple of the number of columns [3]
#>   tb.n tb.c tb.li m.1 m.2 m.3 m.4
#> 1    1    e     9   1   0   0   0
#> 2    1    0     0   0   1   0   0
#> 3    0    1     0   0   0   1   0
#> 4    4    h  text   0   0   0   1
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[2:3, 1] <- tbl2[1:2, 2])
#> No common type for `value`
#> <double[,4]> and `x` <tbl_df<
#> n : integer
#> c : character
#> li: list
#> >>.
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[2:3, 2] <- tbl[1:2, 1])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li      m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2â€¦     1     1     1
#> 3     3 g     <int [3â€¦     2     2     2
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1â€¦     0     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>

x[i, j] <- canâ€™t append rows.

with_df(df[5, "n"] <- list(0))
#>   n    c         li
#> 1 1    e          9
#> 2 2    f     10, 11
#> 3 3    g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 4    h       text
#> 5 0 <NA>       NULL
 
with_tbl(tbl[5, "n"] <- list(0))
#> Vector of length 5 cannot be
#> recycled to
#> length 4. Only vectors of length one
#> can
#> be recycled.

Definition of x[[i, j]] <- a.

i must be a numeric vector of length 1. x[[i, j]] <- a is equivalent to x[i, ][[j]] <- a.9

with_df(df[[1, 1]] <- 0)
#>   n c         li
#> 1 0 e          9
#> 2 2 f     10, 11
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 4 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1, 1]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df(df[1, ][[1]] <- 0)
#>   n c         li
#> 1 0 e          9
#> 2 2 f     10, 11
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 4 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[1, ][[1]] <- 0)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     0 e     <dbl [1]>
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df(df[[1, 3]] <- list(NULL))
#>   n c         li
#> 1 1 e       NULL
#> 2 2 f     10, 11
#> 3 3 g 12, 13, 14
#> 4 4 h       text
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1, 3]] <- list(NULL))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <NULL>   
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_tbl(tbl[1, ][[3]] <- list(NULL))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>       n c     li       
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   
#> 1     1 e     <NULL>   
#> 2     2 f     <int [2]>
#> 3     3 g     <int [3]>
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1]>
 
with_df2(df2[[1, 1]] <- df[1, ])
#> Error in `[[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> iseq, value = structure(list(n = 1L,
#> : replacement has 1 row, data has 4
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[1, 1]] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li      m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2â€¦     0     1     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3â€¦     0     0     1
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1â€¦     0     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[1, ][[1]] <- tbl[1, ])
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li      m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     0     0
#> 2     2 f     <int [2â€¦     0     1     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3â€¦     0     0     1
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1â€¦     0     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
with_df2(df2[[1, 2]] <- t(1:4))
#> Error in x[[jseq]][[iseq]] <- value:
#> more elements supplied than there
#> are to replace
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[[1, 2]] <- t(1:4))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li      m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     2     3
#> 2     2 f     <int [2â€¦     0     1     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3â€¦     0     0     1
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1â€¦     0     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
with_tbl2(tbl2[1, ][[2]] <- t(1:4))
#> # A tibble: 4 x 2
#>    tb$n $c    $li      m[,1]  [,2]  [,3]
#>   <int> <chr> <list>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1     1 e     <dbl [1â€¦     1     2     3
#> 2     2 f     <int [2â€¦     0     1     0
#> 3     3 g     <int [3â€¦     0     0     1
#> 4     4 h     <chr [1â€¦     0     0     0
#> # â€¦ with 1 more variable: [,4] <dbl>
 
df[[1:2, 1]]
#> Error in col[[i, exact = exact]]:
#> attempt to select more than one
#> element in vectorIndex
 
tbl[[1:2, 1]]
#> Error in error_need_scalar(): could
#> not find function
#> "error_need_scalar"
 
with_df(df[[1:2, 1]] <- 0)
#> Error in `[[<-.data.frame`(`*tmp*`,
#> 1:2, 1, value = 0): only a single
#> element should be replaced
 
with_tbl(tbl[[1:2, 1]] <- 0)
#> Error in error_need_scalar(): could
#> not find function
#> "error_need_scalar"

NB: vctrs::vec_size(a) must equal 1. Unlike x[i, ] <-, x[[i, ]] <- is not valid.

stopifnot(identical(tbl, new_tbl()))

  1. NB: x[j][[jj]] is equal to x[[ j[[jj]] ]], in particular x[j][[1]] is equal to x[[j]] for scalar numeric or integer j.â†©

  2. Row subsetting x[i, ] is not defined in terms of x[[j]][i] because that definition does not generalise to matrix and data frame columns. For efficiency and backward compatibility, i is converted to an integer vector by vctrs::vec_as_index(i, nrow(x)) first.â†©

  3. x[,] is equivalent to x[] because x[, j] is equivalent to x[j].â†©

  4. A more efficient implementation of x[i, j] would forward to x[j][i, ].â†©

  5. Cell subsetting x[[i, j]] is not defined in terms of x[[j]][[i]] because that definition does not generalise to list, matrix and data frame columns. A more efficient implementation of x[[i, j]] would check that j is a scalar and forward to x[i, j][[1]].â†©

  6. $ behaves almost completely symmetrical to [[ when comparing subsetting and subassignment.â†©

  7. x[i, ] are symmetrical for subset and subassignment.â†©

  8. x[i, j] is symmetrical for subsetting and subassignment. A more efficient implementation of x[i, j] <- a would forward to x[j][i, ] <- a.â†©

  9. x[[i, j]] is symmetrical for subsetting and subassignment. An efficient implementation would check that i and j are scalar and forward to x[i, j][[1]] <- a.â†©
